title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Jay Powell, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress there was “hope for a return to more normal conditions” this year but signalled that the central bank intended to maintain its heavy support of the economy.

He pointed to no early tightening of monetary policy or drawdown of asset purchases, even with a brighter economic outlook — and helped technology shares claw back most of their losses after a sharp fall during early trading in New York.

Speaking to the Senate banking committee on Tuesday, Powell offered one of his more optimistic assessments of economic conditions since the start of the pandemic, but stressed there were still big downside risks to the recovery that justified the central bank's ultra-easy stance.

Although the number of new cases and hospitalisations has been falling, and ongoing vaccinations offer hope, the economic recovery remains “uneven and far from complete”, he said, arguing that stubbornly low inflation was still a greater danger than a durable acceleration. 

“The economy is a long way from our employment and inflation goals, and it is likely to take some time for substantial further progress to be achieved,” he said.

The prospect for an improvement in the US Covid-19 situation — combined with new large-scale fiscal stimulus backed by congressional Democrats and President Joe Biden — has prompted many economists to upgrade their growth forecasts for 2021. Some have warned that a burst in economic activity could trigger an unhealthy jump in inflation.

During the testimony, Powell was repeatedly pressed by senators on the merits of Biden's $1.9tn stimulus plan, but declined to take a position. If enacted, the package will be a risky experiment, writes Martin Wolf, and it might be no bad thing if it ended up somewhat smaller than now proposed. 

Coronavirus digest

  • The US regulator urged vaccine makers to begin studies on shots adapted for new virus variants, adding they could avoid lengthy trials for approvals.

  • Future vaccines depend on test subjects that are in short supply: monkeys. (FT, NYT)

  • England's schools will be given a further £400m to help pupils catch up on lost learning. UK ministers are weighing up using Covid-19 tests as an alternative to “vaccine passports”.

  • Malaysia rolls out Covid-19 vaccinations today under a state of emergency.

  • Turkey, home to tens of thousands of Uighur exiles, must perform a balancing act with Beijing as it seeks closer investment ties and Covid-19 vaccines.

  • Central Europe is bracing for a third wave of infections as the Czech Republic warned that its health system is on the brink of “absolute exhaustion”.

  • Hotel Group Accor swings to €2bn full-year loss, in a sharp reversal from the French group's €464m net profit in 2019.

  • Demand for disinfectant pushes Reckitt Benckiser to record profits.

For many African Americans, hesitancy about Covid-19 vaccines comes from a deep-rooted suspicion of the authorities, stretching back to slavery. Dr Marcella Nunez-Smith, one of Joe Biden's top health advisers, has warned that anti-vaccination campaigners are targeting black Americans with misinformation about jabs. (FT)

Follow the latest Covid-19 news with our live blog.

In the news

Bond investors suffer The global bond market is suffering its worst start to a year since 2015 as investors grow confident that the Covid-19 vaccine rollout will boost economic growth and fan inflationary pressures for the first time in decades. Richard Bernstein argues that the Fed should not rush to coddle bond investors' tantrums and let the financial markets soothe themselves. (FT)

US Capitol assault hearing Security officials in charge of guarding the US Capitol during the January 6 riot said they did not see an FBI memo warning of potential domestic extremism, blaming a failure in intelligence sharing during the first public hearing on the attack by a pro-Trump mob that left five people dead and resulted in scores of criminal charges. (FT)

EU factories raise goods prices European manufacturers are passing higher input costs on to their customers, sending eurozone inflation to its highest level for almost a year as shortages of materials and soaring shipping costs disrupted supply chains. (FT)

Texas grid operator directors quit The independent directors of the embattled Texas grid operator resigned on Tuesday as the financial and political fallout from last week's electricity crisis continued to mount. The Electric Reliability Council of Texas is facing calls for reform and at least two lawsuits. (FT)

London should be centre of ‘Spac revolution', says ex-LSE chief The City should become a global centre for special purpose acquisition companies to fend off rivals after Brexit, say former London Stock Exchange head Xavier Rolet and Vote Leave co-founder Matthew Elliott. Spacs have become one of the hottest areas of finance over the past year, with New York dominating the market. (FT)

US considers sanctions against Russia over SolarWinds hack The Biden administration is planning a package of measures, including sanctions, to punish Russia over the SolarWinds espionage campaign that struck at the heart of the US government. Vladimir Putin and his Belarusian counterpart Alexander Lukashenko have shunned EU sanctions over their crackdowns. (FT)

Mitsubishi set to reverse plan for Europe withdrawal A decision to have Renault produce Mitsubishi cars at its French factories, if finalised, would force the Japanese company to justify its U-turn — and face down accusations it yielded to alliance partner Renault's campaign to protect French jobs. (FT)

India risks tax clash with Biden Narendra Modi's government this month announced one of the world's toughest taxes on foreign technology companies, in the latest of several examples of bold but contentious steps New Delhi has taken to assert control over US tech companies. (FT)

Biden to order review of foreign supply chains US president Joe Biden will order a review of critical foreign supply chains to reduce America's dependence on China and other rivals for everything from rare earths and drug ingredients to semiconductors. (FT)

UK companies pressed to appoint more women executives Ministers urged companies to appoint more women to senior executive positions following the end of the Hampton-Alexander review into boardroom gender diversity. As of last month, there were no longer any all-male boards in the FTSE 350, but more than 100 companies failed to meet a target of having at least a third of board positions held by women. (FT)

The days ahead

Powell testifies Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell is scheduled to testify before the House Financial Services panel on Wednesday. (FT)

Andrew Bailey addresses Treasury Committee The Bank of England governor appears before the UK Treasury Committee on Wednesday. (FT)

Earnings round-up Booking, Lowe's Companies, Royal Bank of Canada, Lloyds, Metro Bank, Nvidia Corp, William Hill and Petrofac are set to report. (FT)

What else we're reading

Car chip shortage exposes supply chain fragility What started out as “temporary” lay-offs at a General Motors' plant soon became “indefinite”. The carmaker was responding to a crippling shortage of chips used to build modern vehicles, which has exposed the fragility of US supply chains.

  • On top of the semiconductor shortage, Nissan is wrestling with a surge in prices of precious metals.

  • Apple is considering shifting from a parts supplier to an assembler in its search for a partner in autonomous electric vehicles. But the courtship is double-edged for vehicle manufacturers, writes Kana Inagaki. (FT)

Myanmar protest movement defies military Furious at the military's nullification of an election and arrest of Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar protesters have taken to the streets in a civil disobedience movement that has proved tenacious in the face of internet blackouts, night-time arrests and security forces' deadly firing of live rounds. (FT)

Joe Biden can save global migration from the deep freeze Few things can avert a lasting chill on migration, but reform in the opposite direction by the world's most powerful country is one of them, writes Janan Ganesh. Through example and sheer numbers, an open US could bring an open world. (FT)

How much wealth do you need to join the 1%? Joining the world's richest is never easy, and it is especially hard in Monaco, where it takes $8m. About half that amount is required in Switzerland and the US, according to research by Knight Frank. Singapore also ranks highly. (Bloomberg)

Don't let gig economy companies rewrite the law When your business model turns out to be against the law, do you change the business model or change the law? Gig economy companies such as Uber want to do the latter, writes Sarah O'Connor, and if they succeed it could change the world of work profoundly. (FT)

Podcast of the day

FT News Briefing In today's rundown of the most important global business stories: Jay Powell indicates the central bank will maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy. Plus, the FT's banking editor, Stephen Morris, explains why the global bank HSBC is pivoting back to its roots in Asia. Listen to today's FT News Briefing for more. (FT)
